topics.title: The Gini Coefficient: One Number to Measure Unfairness

hook.text: A single number between 0 and 1 tells you how equally a country shares its wealth. Zero means perfect equality.

buildup.text: Corrado Gini invented the coefficient in 1912. It compares the actual income distribution to a perfectly equal one.

discovery.text: Denmark scores 0.28 (very equal). The US scores 0.39. South Africa scores 0.63 â€” the world's most unequal nation.

twist.text: The Gini has a blind spot: a country of millionaires and a country of paupers can have the same Gini if incomes are.

climax.text: No single number captures inequality perfectly.

punchline.text: One number can't explain inequality. But it can reveal it.

quiz.question: What does a Gini coefficient of 0 represent?
options: Perfect equality â€” everyone has the same income

topics.title: Income vs. Wealth: Two Different Inequalities

hook.text: A junior doctor earns $200,000 but owes $300,000 in loans. A retiree earns $30,000 but owns a $2 million house.

buildup.text: Income is what you earn. Wealth is what you own minus what you owe.

discovery.text: Income inequality is high. Wealth inequality is extreme.

twist.text: Wealth compounds. A $100,000 inheritance invested at 7% becomes $800,000 in 30 years.

climax.text: Focusing only on income hides the deeper inequality.

punchline.text: Income is what you make this year. Wealth is what your family made for.

quiz.question: Why is wealth inequality typically greater than income inequality?
options: Wealth compounds over time and across generations, amplifying initial advantages

topics.title: The Top 1%: Who Are They Really?

hook.text: To be in the global top 1%, you need an income of $60,000.

buildup.text: In the US, the top 1% threshold is $540,000.

discovery.text: But within the 1%, inequality is extreme. The top 0.

twist.text: Most of the 1% are doctors, lawyers, and business owners â€” not billionaires.

climax.text: Talking about 'the 1%' lumps together a dentist earning $500,000 with Jeff Bezos earning $500,000 per minute.

punchline.text: The 1% is a big tent. The real story is the 0.001% at the very top.

quiz.question: What income puts someone in the global top 1%?
options: About $60,000 â€” a middle-class salary in wealthy countries

topics.title: The Elephant Curve: Globalization's Winners and Losers

hook.text: One graph shaped like an elephant explains why both Chinese workers and Western elites love globalization.

buildup.text: Branko Milanovic plotted income growth from 1988-2008 by global percentile.

discovery.text: The elephant's body: massive gains for Asia's emerging middle class. The trunk: huge gains for the global ultra-rich.

twist.text: The Western middle class â€” globally in the 75th-90th percentile â€” saw almost zero real income growth for 20 years.

climax.text: The elephant curve explains populism, Brexit, and Trump.

punchline.text: Globalization worked for the world's poor and the world's rich.

quiz.question: What does the 'dip' in the elephant curve represent?
options: Stagnant incomes for the Western middle class during 20 years of globalization

topics.title: The Kuznets Curve: Does Growth Fix Inequality?

hook.text: Simon Kuznets proposed a comforting idea: inequality rises during industrialization, then falls as nations get richer.

buildup.text: The evidence seemed perfect. Industrial Britain and America saw inequality rise.

discovery.text: Kuznets won a Nobel Prize. Policymakers relaxed: just focus on growth, and equality will follow naturally.

twist.text: Since 1980, inequality has surged in every developed nation. The curve didn't turn down again.

climax.text: The mid-century equality wasn't automatic â€” it was built by policy: progressive taxes, strong unions, public education.

punchline.text: Growth doesn't cure inequality. Policy does.

quiz.question: Why did the Kuznets curve theory prove incomplete?
options: Post-1980 rising inequality showed that declining inequality was driven by policy choices, not automatic growth

topics.title: Education Premium: Why Your Degree Is Worth Less Than It Used To Be

hook.text: In 1970, a college graduate earned 40% more than a high school graduate. Today, they earn 80% more.

buildup.text: The 'education premium' measures how much more educated workers earn.

discovery.text: Claudia Goldin called it a race between technology and education. When education keeps up, inequality falls.

twist.text: But today's premium is eroding for new graduates. Student debt eats the extra earnings.

climax.text: Education is still the most powerful equalizer.

punchline.text: A degree still pays. It just costs more and takes longer to break even.

quiz.question: What is the 'race between technology and education'?
options: When technology creates skill demand faster than education creates skilled workers, inequality rises

topics.title: Winner-Take-All Markets: Why Superstars Earn Millions

hook.text: The world's best soccer player earns 10,000x more than the 500th-best. But he's not 10,000x more talented.

buildup.text: Winner-take-all markets: small differences in skill produce enormous differences in reward.

discovery.text: Before recording, a singer performed for 500 people. Now Spotify lets the top singer reach 500 million.

twist.text: This logic now applies beyond entertainment.

climax.text: Technology doesn't just reward talent â€” it concentrates rewards.

punchline.text: In a global market, second place earns a fraction of first.

quiz.question: Why do 'winner-take-all' markets produce extreme inequality?
options: Technology lets small talent differences reach global audiences, concentrating rewards at the top

topics.title: Tax Havens: Where the World's Wealth Hides

hook.text: An estimated $36 trillion sits in offshore tax havens.

buildup.text: Tax havens offer near-zero tax rates and total secrecy.

discovery.text: Gabriel Zucman estimated that 8% of the world's financial wealth is held offshore.

twist.text: Tax havens aren't just tropical islands.

climax.text: Tax havens make inequality worse by ensuring that the wealthiest pay the least.

punchline.text: The richest people in the world are also the hardest to tax.

quiz.question: How much of the world's financial wealth is estimated to be held offshore?

topics.title: Rent-Seeking: Getting Rich Without Creating Value

hook.text: A lobbyist earns $500/hour convincing Congress to give his client a tax break worth billions.

buildup.text: Rent-seeking: manipulating rules to capture wealth without creating any.

discovery.text: The US pharmaceutical industry spends $300 million/year lobbying.

twist.text: Rent-seeking isn't corruption â€” it's legal.

climax.text: When getting rich by changing rules pays more than building something new.

punchline.text: The most profitable business in America isn't making things.

quiz.question: What is rent-seeking in economics?
options: Manipulating rules and regulations to capture wealth without creating new value for society

topics.title: Intergenerational Mobility: Can You Escape Your Birth?

hook.text: A child born poor in Denmark has a 12% chance of staying poor as an adult. In the US, that chance is 40%. Same ambition.

buildup.text: Social mobility measures how much your parents' income predicts yours. High mobility means anyone can rise.

discovery.text: The 'Great Gatsby Curve' shows that countries with higher inequality also have lower mobility.

twist.text: The American Dream is statistically more achievable in Scandinavia than in America.

climax.text: Mobility isn't about individual effort â€” it's about systems.

punchline.text: Meritocracy is a beautiful idea. The data says it's mostly a myth.

quiz.question: What does the 'Great Gatsby Curve' show?
options: Countries with higher inequality tend to have lower social mobility

topics.title: Piketty's r > g: Capital Eats the Economy

hook.text: Thomas Piketty's 700-page book can be summarized in three characters: r > g. Return on capital exceeds economic growth.

buildup.text: If your investments grow at 5% and the economy grows at 2%, the rich get richer faster than everyone else.

discovery.text: Piketty analyzed 200 years of data across 20 countries.

twist.text: World wars and progressive taxation compressed wealth in the 20th century.

climax.text: r > g means capitalism, left alone, produces dynastic wealth. The solution Piketty proposes: a global wealth tax.

punchline.text: Capital grows faster than the economy. Unless you tax it.

quiz.question: What does Piketty's formula 'r > g' mean?
options: The return on capital exceeds economic growth, causing wealth to concentrate automatically over time
Rich countries grow faster than poor ones

topics.title: CEO Pay: 350 Times the Worker

hook.text: In 1965, CEOs earned 21x their average worker. Today, it's 351x. Did CEOs get 17 times more talented in 60 years?

buildup.text: CEO compensation exploded from $1.5 million (1978) to $27.8 million (2021) in inflation-adjusted dollars.

discovery.text: Stock options are the secret weapon. CEOs are paid in equity that multiplies with share prices.

twist.text: Research shows CEO pay is poorly correlated with performance.

climax.text: CEO pay isn't set by markets â€” it's set by boards of directors who are often friends or allies.

punchline.text: CEOs don't earn 351x more because they work 351x harder.

quiz.question: What primarily drives the explosion in CEO compensation since the 1970s?
options: Stock options that multiply with share prices, plus boards that set pay without true market discipline

topics.title: Monopoly Power: When Competition Dies

hook.text: In 1980, the top four firms in most US industries controlled 25% of the market. By 2020, it was 45%.

buildup.text: Mergers and acquisitions eliminate competitors. Tech giants buy startups before they become threats.

discovery.text: Corporate profits as a share of GDP hit record highs while labor's share hit record lows.

twist.text: Market power is self-reinforcing: monopoly profits fund lobbying that prevents antitrust enforcement that could.

climax.text: Rising market concentration transfers income from consumers and workers to shareholders.

punchline.text: When four companies control your choices, 'free market' is just a slogan.

quiz.question: How does increasing market concentration contribute to inequality?
options: It doesn't â€” monopolies help everyone
Higher profits flow to shareholders (mostly wealthy) while workers get less and consumers pay more

topics.title: Dark Money in Politics: Wealth Buys Influence

hook.text: The Koch brothers spent $889 million on the 2016 US election cycle.

buildup.text: Citizens United (2010) allowed unlimited political spending by corporations and individuals.

discovery.text: Studies show US policy outcomes correlate strongly with the preferences of the wealthy and poorly with average.

twist.text: It's not just campaign donations. Think tanks, media ownership.

climax.text: Economic inequality and political inequality feed each other.

punchline.text: In theory, every citizen gets one vote. In practice.

quiz.question: What did the Citizens United ruling enable?
options: Unlimited political spending by corporations and individuals, dramatically increasing money in politics

topics.title: Housing Wealth: The Great Divide

hook.text: If you bought a house in San Francisco in 2010 for $700,000, it's now worth $1.5 million.

buildup.text: For most families, their home is their biggest asset. When housing prices rise, homeowners get richer automatically.

discovery.text: Homeownership rates diverge by race and age. 74% of white Americans own homes vs. 45% of Black Americans.

twist.text: NIMBYism â€” opposition to new housing â€” is the most effective wealth-hoarding mechanism.

climax.text: Housing is where inequality, race, geography, and generational wealth collide.

punchline.text: The biggest wealth creator in America isn't the stock market.

quiz.question: How does NIMBYism contribute to inequality?
options: Blocking new construction protects existing homeowners' values while pricing out renters and younger buyers

topics.title: Global Inequality: The Lottery of Birth

hook.text: Where you're born determines 60% of your lifetime income. Your talent, effort, and choices control the other 40%.

buildup.text: An average American earns $65,000/year. An average Congolese earns $500. Same species, same planet, 130x income gap.

discovery.text: Branko Milanovic showed that between-country inequality is far larger than within-country inequality.

twist.text: A poor person in the US is richer than 85% of humanity. Poverty is relative within countries but absolute across them.

climax.text: Global inequality is fundamentally a question of borders.

punchline.text: Your biggest economic advantage isn't your degree. It's your passport.

quiz.question: What determines the largest share of a person's lifetime income?
options: Where they are born â€” the country of birth accounts for about 60% of lifetime income variation

topics.title: Colonial Legacies: How History Made Some Nations Poor

hook.text: Haiti paid France 150 million francs â€” 10x its annual revenue â€” as reparations for gaining independence.

buildup.text: Colonialism extracted wealth from colonies through forced labor, resource theft, and unequal trade.

discovery.text: Acemoglu and Robinson showed that colonizers built extractive institutions in resource-rich colonies and inclusive.

twist.text: Many post-colonial borders were drawn arbitrarily, splitting ethnic groups and combining rivals.

climax.text: Global inequality isn't random. It's the product of 500 years of colonial extraction.

punchline.text: Many poor countries were made poor. They didn't start that way.

quiz.question: How do colonial-era institutions affect modern inequality?
options: They don't â€” colonialism ended decades ago
Extractive institutions created by colonizers persisted after independence, shaping governance and poverty patterns today

topics.title: The Resource Curse: When Wealth Makes You Poor

hook.text: Nigeria has earned $600 billion from oil since 1960. Yet 40% of its population lives in extreme poverty.

buildup.text: The resource curse: countries rich in oil, diamonds, or minerals often have slower growth, more corruption.

discovery.text: Easy resource revenue reduces the pressure to build institutions, diversify the economy.

twist.text: Norway escaped the curse with a sovereign wealth fund that saves oil revenue for future generations. It now holds $1.

climax.text: Resources aren't inherently cursed â€” bad institutions are. The same oil that impoverished Nigeria enriched Norway.

punchline.text: Oil doesn't curse nations. Bad governance does.

quiz.question: How did Norway avoid the 'resource curse'?
options: It created a sovereign wealth fund to save oil revenue and invest it for future generations

topics.title: The Poverty Trap: When Being Poor Keeps You Poor

hook.text: A farmer too poor to buy fertilizer gets a small harvest. A small harvest means she can't afford fertilizer next year.

buildup.text: Poverty traps are self-reinforcing cycles.

discovery.text: At the national level: poor countries can't afford good infrastructure, which deters investment, which keeps them poor.

twist.text: Jeffrey Sachs argued a 'big push' of aid could break the trap.

climax.text: Escaping poverty traps requires breaking the cycle at some point.

punchline.text: The cruelest thing about poverty is that it causes itself.

quiz.question: What makes a poverty trap self-reinforcing?
options: Low income prevents investment in health, education, and productivity, which perpetuates low income

topics.title: Foreign Aid: Lifeline or Crutch?

hook.text: Rich nations have given $5 trillion in foreign aid since 1960.

buildup.text: Aid funds vaccinations, schools, and infrastructure. PEPFAR alone saved 25 million lives from AIDS.

discovery.text: But Dambisa Moyo argued that aid creates dependency, empowers corrupt governments.

twist.text: RCT research by Esther Duflo showed that carefully designed, targeted aid works.

climax.text: The aid debate isn't about generosity vs. selfishness. It's about what actually works.

punchline.text: The question isn't whether to give aid. It's whether the aid works.

quiz.question: What did Esther Duflo's research show about foreign aid?
options: Carefully designed, evidence-based, targeted aid programs can be highly effective

topics.title: Inequality and Health: The Social Gradient of Death

hook.text: Ride the London Underground from Westminster to Canning Town â€” 6 stops east. Life expectancy drops 1 year per station.

buildup.text: Michael Marmot discovered the 'social gradient'.

discovery.text: Inequality kills through stress, poor nutrition, limited healthcare access, and environmental exposure.

twist.text: Even rich people in unequal societies are less healthy than rich people in equal societies.

climax.text: Health inequality isn't about personal choices.

punchline.text: Your income predicts your death date better than your diet does.

quiz.question: What did Marmot's research reveal about health and inequality?
options: Only the very poor have health problems
Health worsens at every step down the income ladder â€” a continuous social gradient, not just poverty

topics.title: Inequality and Crime: When the Gap Gets Dangerous

hook.text: The US has 5x the murder rate of Western Europe. It's also 2x more unequal. Coincidence? 50 years of research says no.

buildup.text: Across countries and US states, higher inequality correlates with higher crime â€” especially violent crime.

discovery.text: Inequality creates relative deprivation: seeing others prosper while you struggle breeds frustration, resentment.

twist.text: It's not poverty alone that drives crime â€” it's the gap.

climax.text: Inequality corrodes social trust and cohesion.

punchline.text: Crime doesn't rise because people are poor.

quiz.question: What drives the relationship between inequality and crime?
options: Relative deprivation â€” the visible gap between rich and poor erodes social trust and increases risk-taking

topics.title: Inequality and Democracy: Can They Coexist?

hook.text: In a true democracy, the majority could vote to redistribute wealth from the rich minority. So why doesn't it happen?

buildup.text: Extreme inequality gives the wealthy disproportionate political power through lobbying, media ownership.

discovery.text: Gilens and Page found that US policy reflects the preferences of the wealthy almost perfectly and average citizens'.

twist.text: Populist movements emerge when people feel democracy has been captured.

climax.text: Extreme inequality and democracy are in tension.

punchline.text: Democracy promises equal voice. Inequality delivers unequal volume.

quiz.question: What did Gilens and Page find about US policymaking?
options: Policy outcomes closely match wealthy Americans' preferences but show almost no correlation with average citizens' wishes

topics.title: Inequality and Growth: Do They Help or Hurt Each Other?

hook.text: For decades, economists said inequality was the price of growth.

buildup.text: The old view: inequality incentivizes hard work and risk-taking. Taxing the rich discourages investment.

discovery.text: IMF research found that societies with lower inequality sustain growth longer.

twist.text: Redistribution â€” taxes and transfers â€” doesn't hurt growth in most cases.

climax.text: The growth-vs-equality tradeoff is largely a myth.

punchline.text: Inequality isn't the price of growth. It's often the obstacle to it.

quiz.question: What did IMF research find about inequality and economic growth?
options: More inequality always means more growth
Societies with lower inequality sustain growth longer; moderate redistribution doesn't hurt growth

topics.title: Universal Basic Income: Free Money for Everyone?

hook.text: What if every citizen received $1,000/month â€” no strings attached? Milton Friedman liked the idea.

buildup.text: UBI: a regular cash payment to every citizen regardless of employment.

discovery.text: Finland's UBI experiment found recipients were happier, healthier, and slightly more likely to work.

twist.text: Critics argue UBI is too expensive and would cause inflation. A $1,000/month US UBI would cost $3.

climax.text: UBI forces a fundamental question: do we trust people to spend money well? The evidence increasingly says yes.

punchline.text: The simplest antipoverty policy is giving people money.

quiz.question: What did Finland's UBI experiment show?
options: Recipients were happier, healthier, and slightly more likely to work than the control group

topics.title: Progressive Taxation: Making the Rich Pay More

hook.text: In 1944, the US taxed income over $200,000 at 94%. The economy boomed.

buildup.text: Progressive taxation: higher earners pay a higher percentage.

discovery.text: The US, UK, and most developed nations used high top tax rates from the 1940s-1970s.

twist.text: Warren Buffett famously noted he pays a lower effective tax rate than his secretary.

climax.text: Tax policy is the most direct tool for reducing inequality.

punchline.text: History's highest growth happened under history's highest tax rates.

quiz.question: What was the top US income tax rate in 1944?
options: 94% â€” and the economy boomed during this period

topics.title: The Nordic Model: Equality Without Sacrifice

hook.text: Denmark, Sweden, and Norway have the world's lowest inequality, highest happiness.

buildup.text: The Nordic model: high taxes, generous welfare states, strong unions, free education, universal healthcare.

discovery.text: Nordic countries rank among the top 10 globally for innovation, business competitiveness, and GDP per capita.

twist.text: The model works partly because of cultural homogeneity and trust.

climax.text: The Nordic model proves that equality and prosperity aren't opposites.

punchline.text: Turns out high taxes and happy citizens can coexist. The Nordics proved it.

quiz.question: What paradox does the Nordic model resolve?
options: High taxes and generous welfare are compatible with â€” and may support â€” strong economic performance and innovation
Only small countries can be equal

topics.title: Land Reform: Redistributing the Oldest Wealth

hook.text: In South Africa, 72% of farmland is owned by white farmers who are 8% of the population.

buildup.text: Land reform: redistributing land from large owners to landless peasants.

discovery.text: Japan's 1946 land reform broke up feudal estates and created a class of small farmers.

twist.text: Zimbabwe's land reform in 2000 redistributed farms to political allies, not farmers.

climax.text: Land reform shows that how redistribution happens matters as much as whether it happens.

punchline.text: Redistributing land can end poverty or create it â€” depending on how it's done.

quiz.question: Why was Japan's postwar land reform successful while Zimbabwe's failed?
options: Japan redistributed to actual farmers with proper implementation; Zimbabwe gave land to political allies, destroying agricultural output

topics.title: Reparations: Can You Repair the Past With Money?

hook.text: Germany paid $80 billion in reparations to Holocaust survivors and Israel.

buildup.text: Reparations: payments or programs to compensate groups for historical injustice.

discovery.text: Ta-Nehisi Coates argued that 250 years of slavery, followed by 100 years of discrimination.

twist.text: Opponents ask: who pays? Who receives? A white immigrant from Poland in 1990? A wealthy Black person? The logistics.

climax.text: Reparations aren't just about checks. They could include education investment, homeownership programs.

punchline.text: Reparations ask an uncomfortable question.

quiz.question: What forms can reparations take beyond direct cash payments?
options: Only cash payments count as reparations
Education investment, homeownership programs, and community development targeting historically harmed communities

topics.title: Inequality and Education: The Opportunity Gap

hook.text: A child from a top-income family hears 30 million more words by age 3 than a child from a poor family.

buildup.text: Rich families spend 7x more on enrichment â€” tutors, camps, travel. By college application time, inequality is baked in.

discovery.text: School funding tied to property taxes means wealthy neighborhoods get better schools.

twist.text: Even free college doesn't equalize. Poor students lack networks, mentors.

climax.text: Educational inequality reproduces economic inequality across generations.

punchline.text: Education is the great equalizer â€” unless inequality reaches it first.

quiz.question: Why does school funding tied to property taxes increase inequality?
